Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2010 02:33AM funsizejen wrote: My mx was in February, and just in the last month or so I've noticed a big improvement.  I can even use my seatbelt correctly now!  I think, in time, you'll see a big improvement.
Posts.Title: hypersensitivity post-mastectomy joane Artlover56

Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2011 07:44PM funsizejen wrote: I was diagnosed with ALH in my left breast in 9/09.  I had the lumpectomy and then scheduled a consult with an oncologist to talk about risk.  The oncologist ordered an MRI and a different lesion was found in the other breast, it was biopsied, and it was indeed cancer...the new lesion was never seen on the mammogram.  My advice would be that if you feel that there may be more going on than the ALH, see if you can get an MRI just to get a better picture of what's going on.  The odds are overwhelmingly good that there is nothing more than the ALH, but you wil be glad to know that for sure!
Posts.Title: Anyone w/ ALH on biopsy get different results after surgery? tjohnson1971 funsizejen

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2011 07:00PM funsizejen wrote: Looking back, I really can't think of any symptoms.  I'm adopted, so I don't have a family history that I know of.  It is so unlikely that anything else will be found after your lumpectomy, but I think you'll get some peace of mind from having the mri.  I know it's easy to say, but try not to worry!  Please update when you can!
Posts.Title: Anyone w/ ALH on biopsy get different results after surgery? tjohnson1971 funsizejen

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2010 09:48PM funsizejen wrote: I had a photographer friend do this for me.  She was so happy to do this for me, and I am glad I did it!  I am normally very conservative with this sort of thing, but she did some very pretty topless pics and some with lingerie.  It was a couple of months after my bmx before I could even look at them, but I am glad I have pics of my old girls!

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2013 08:01PM funsizejen wrote: My cancer center offered free private counseling to patients.  I was able to go after I finished treatment and needed help processing all that had happened.  I went a couple of times and felt much better.  Maybe you can ask your onc about a service like this.  Soooo helpful in moving forward.

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2010 11:10PM funsizejen wrote: I'm sorry you have to go through this!  I lost a lot of sleep worrying about the wire placement for my lumpectomy, but it was not as bad as I expected.  I felt a pinch and some tugging, but it only lasted for a few short moments.  Very do-able.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: Second stereotactic showed the same worriedwoman worriedwoman

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2011 11:16PM funsizejen wrote: Here is how I decided who to tell:  I asked myself  "If this person was diagnosed with cancer and didn't tell ME, would I be mad?"  If the answer was yes, I told.  Good luck with these decisions.  It seems unfair to have to worry about everyone else's feelings at a time like this.
Posts.Title: How did you handle telling family when diagnosed? watchfuleye funsizejen

Posts.Content: Oct 27, 2015 12:15PM funsizejen wrote: I'm sorry you are finding yourself in this situation, AZ, The decision-making process is so difficult, because no one can tell you exactly what to do. There are so many options. I can tell you that I personally opted for the mastectomy because I didn't want to go through this same diagnosis again. I had cancer in one breast and numerous suspicious areas in the other. I felt like I would always be worried and having biopsies every few months, So, the pros are that my breasts are reconstructed and symmetrical and I haven't had any more breast cancer scares. The con is that I no longer have real breasts! Wishing you wisdom and clarity as you make your decisions!
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy or Mastecomy AZ100615 kdtheatre

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2010 11:37PM funsizejen wrote: I'm sorry you're going through this.  I had an exisional biopsy/lumpectomy last year.  It was a wire guided biopsy.  If that's part of your procedure, you'll show up at the hospital early and go to radiology.  You will have a mammogram and have a teeny-thin wire inserted in your breast to help the surgeon find the area to be excised.  It was not as big of a deal as I feared.  Then, you'll go to the surgery area and get prepped for surgery.  Then you have your surgery and wake up in recovery!  I had an oral pain pill before I left the surgery center, then one at home that night, and then tylenol for a day or two.  Also, a sports bra will compress the area and make you more comfortable.  You will do great...good luck!!!
Posts.Title: can someone describe excisional biopsy? momand2kids brooke1120

Posts.Content: May 16, 2010 07:25AM funsizejen wrote: The girls from my work threw a going-away party for my breasts....it was awesome!  The invitations read..."Ta-ta to the ta-tas......thanks for all the mammaries".  They even brought cupcakes that were decorated to look like breasts.  It was great to feel all their love and support and even have a few laughs!
Posts.Title: Bye Bye Boobie party TerriD jeaniept

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2010 11:50AM funsizejen wrote: Hi!  I'm new here, too.  I had my very first mammo in August, suspicious calcifications were found in both breasts.  I had to have the stereotactic biopsies on both.  Left side showed ALH, and right side was ok.  Had a screening MRI on the recommendation of my surgeon, and now have to have another biopsy on the right side (tonmorrow!).   My understanding is that IF atypia is found, in either breast, then you're at higher risk in both breasts.  I'm sorry...I know I'm not a lot of help.  I just wanted you to know that you're not alone!!  Odds are, your test results will be just fine! Jen
